subject: P1 From a Long Time Ago
content: Hello,. . I was reviewing my grades thus far in the class and one that bothered me was my P1 score. It came to my knowledge that I scored poorly because my functions expected a sorted list when it was to supposed to sort the list within every function. As a result, many functions with correct implementations failed on one small detail. I therefore feel the grade doesn't reflect my mastery of the material.. . I realize P1 was way long ago, and I apologize if this is a bother. In addition, I know EECS 280 has a strict grading policy when it comes to autograder, but I thought this may be an exception.. Thanks,. Daniel
i_answer: Hi Daniel, unfortunately, cases like this come up a lot and it would not be fair to give credit to some students and not others. Luckily, project 1 is only a small portion of your grade and you were able to learn from it so you can better test your code for future projects.

subject: independence of the images functions
content: should functions like images_set_pixel be able to be called independently of other functions. For example, should we assume that the user initializes the images and rgb channels with images_init before they call images_set_pixel? Or should we call the images_init inside images_set_pixel? (or images_get_pixel)
i_answer: If it says that you'll be passed a valid matrix/image, then you don't have to call matrix/image_init. If you're just passed a matrix/image, then you will have to call matrix/image_init.

subject: Project 1 Grade
content: Good evening,. Sorry to bother but I was just wondering if anyone could provide some clarification about my Project 1 grade; I got an extension for Friday at 8p because I went into quarantine on Tuesday, and the Autograder graded the best submission as of Wednesday instead of my better submission (passed Valgrind) on Thursday. Just wondering if it takes time for it to manually process the extension, or if there was an error. Thank you for your time!
i_answer: The extension was handled correctly in the autograder, and it doesn't appear that there was any error. The autograder grades all of your submissions fully (including the private tests), and then keeps whichever submission attains the highest score overall. Even though you fixed the error mentioned by valgrind, in doing so I'm guessing you introduced a hard to find bug in your percentile function, resulting in less points on the AG, and thus the AG chose your old submit instead of your new one.

subject: P1 sort in main
content: Hello, did autograder go through the functions themselves and not through main? In order to be more efficient with my code, I put the sort function in main before any functions were implemented,. After looking at autograder, I noticed that two of my functions (median and percentile) that didn't work were ones that would require the sort function (mode was unscathed because I used sort in the function before I thought to just put sort in main). I was wondering if there was any way my code could be looked at to determine this- my previous class only looked at main and I thought that this autograder would do the same for the tests. If so, is there any way my grade can be revisited? Thank you!
i_answer: From the P1 spec:.  > The functions in `stats.cpp` must still work when compiled with a different main function.`. . So, they must work for any data, even unsorted data. Thinking with efficiency in mind is a good idea, but unfortunately we can't offer any sort of regrading for the project. P1 is worth a bit less than the other projects, so try not to worry too much and for future projects emphasize unit testing per function.

subject: Valgrind Error
content: Hi! I got a 3/3 on my latest submission but there is a Valgrind error under the main public test and I have totally no idea why it showed up and how to fix it even after reading the previous related posts. Also, I am wondering why the stats private tests did not run? Here are the pictures of the screenshots on the autograder. . . . . As for the Valgrind error, it said there was something wrong with main.cpp line 39 and stats.cpp line 149. Here are my codes.. . . My guess is that on stats.cpp line 149 the [intpart - 1] might be out of the index bound so the error popped up? Can I fix it by adding:. assert(intpart >= 1 && intpart <v.size());. . Last but not least, when I set up Valgrind on my computer, I ran into this problem. Is the Valgrind error related to this problem?. . Thanks in advance. I have struggled with these problems for a long time and still feel pretty lost. It would be great if someone could give me some hints or advice. Much appreciated!!!.
i_answer: I can't tell you whether that code will fix it or not because that's the same as giving you the answer, but I can say checking for edge cases is exactly what you're supposed to do. Think clearly about when you will go out of bounds in relation to the percentile function and what you should do in each case, for example, what if p = 1?There are a couple other piazza posts related to percentile out of bound edge cases, so I'd recommend checking those as well. . . Private test cases are run after your due date to check the implementation of your code - this is where you will get the majority of your points. . . For the final question, I think it's a little hard to do over piazza because I can't see everything in your system, luckily, we're having [set up clinics](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/2/d/e/2PACX-1vSzjDOSYXwV9EDEu2ile37BLZqQYpi2UcHl5s6vXeL9kv1VI-_lXEsP7WfyzREUuZreOopIJ4AIs624/pubhtml?gid=0&single=true) all this week if you can make it to one! I think I've seen this error on Piazza before if you want to check those - I think this might be a similar case to not finding a home page like @781 @558 or a path error similar to @252, apologies I can't help more over Piazza

subject: Question about Mode function in p1
content: I just wanted to ask a question about the mode function for project 1. I know that private tests cannot be revealed to us, but I just wanted to ask if we would have been graded down for not including the sort() function in mode, or was that hint completely optional for this function? Also is there any possible way we can get feedback for p1 now that the grading is done? It helps to know where you went wrong, or at least to be given a hint about where I went wrong for the test cases I didn't pass? Thank you for your time.
i_answer: As long as your implementation worked, you would have received full points for that function. We can't reveal what the private tests are, but you're welcome to come to office hours to discuss your function implementations with an IA!

subject: Is there any way to see why we got a private test case wrong?
content: I missed one test case (stats test mode 1) and was wondering if there was any way I could see why my program failed on that test. I tested it with every possible input I could think of, so I was just wondering what I could have done better.. . I understand if that's not possible though since we aren't allowed to know what the private test cases are, in that case I guess I'll just keep testing it to see where it could have gone wrong.. . Also, if I got a 17/18 on the AG, that means my final grade for project one is a 94.4%, correct?
i_answer: . p1 only counts 5% of total grades. And you only lose 0.3% of the total right now. Don’t be panic. You are still good. . Look at the RME for the mode function and consider the example cases:. . //REQUIRES: v is not empty. //EFFECTS: returns the mode of the numbers in v. //  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mode_(statistics). //  Example: mode({1,2,3}) = 1. //  Example: mode({1,1,2,2}) = 1. //  Example: mode({2,2,1,1}) = 1. //  Example: mode({1,2,1,2}) = 1. //  Example: mode({1,2,1,2,2}) = 2. //  In the event of a tie, return the smallest value (as in the . //  above examples). //HINT 1: use the sort() function provided in p1_library.h. //HINT 2: use a nested loop. //HINT 3: use a variable to remember the most frequent number seen so far

subject: I keep getting a Valgrind error but only in Autograder
content: ==66== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s). ==66==    at 0x51DE258: sqrt (w_sqrt.c:27). ==66==    by 0x405373: stdev(std::vector >) (stats.cpp:151). ==66==    by 0x402DC1: main (stats_public_test.cpp:25). ==66== . ==66== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s). ==66==    at 0x572B6C8: __printf_fp_l (printf_fp.c:381). ==66==    by 0x572A0B8: vfprintf (vfprintf.c:1631). ==66==    by 0x5751A48: vsnprintf (vsnprintf.c:114). ==66==    by 0x4F0EF5B: ??? (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.21). ==66==    by 0x4F3DA56: std::ostreambuf_iterator > std::num_put > >::_M_insert_float(std::ostreambuf_iterator >, std::ios_base&, char, char, double) const (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.21). ==66==    by 0x4F3DD6F: std::num_put > >::do_put(std::ostreambuf_iterator >, std::ios_base&, char, double) const (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.21). ==66==    by 0x4F49FC4: std::ostream& std::ostream::_M_insert(double) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.21). ==66==    by 0x402DE8: main (stats_public_test.cpp:25). ==66==
i_answer: "Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)". This means that there is some uninitialised variable that is being used somewhere.. . "main (stats_public_test.cpp:25)". This give you the file & line where this uninitialised value is being used. Looks like its in a cout statement by the line above "std::ostream& std::ostream...". . Make sure you are not returning an uninitialised value from any of your functions, which would look something like. . int a;     // a will have some garbage integer value and does not have to default to 0.. return a;. .

subject: Autograder most recent submission and best submission
content: If I submitted my code to autograder and got a 3/3 on it but changed it after writing more test cases, will my most recent 3/3 be the one graded, or the first 3/3?
i_answer: It keeps the latest submission with the highest scores. For example, you got 1 2 2 3 3, autograder will keep the last 3 submisison.

subject: Project 1 Ques
content: In the project spec it says once I compile and rune main.exe I should be asked for a filename, then column name, ... etc. but my code only prints hello from main. What am I doing wrong, or not doing so I can fix this? Also what am I supposed to have the function summarize do and is there a specific format I need to use?
i_answer: Once you have finished all the functions in stats.cpp, you have to edit the main.cpp function so it does what the spec outlines (you should be removing that line that causes main.cpp to print "Hello World" or whatever you have).  I would look at this part in the spec for more details on this.. . For the summarize function, essentially what you should be doing is returning a vector of vectors of doubles that holds the number:frequency pairs stored in it.. . ex. if your vector looks like this {1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4}, your summarize function should return something like this { {1, 1}, {2, 1}, {3, 3}, {4, 2} }, as 1 appears once, 2 appears once, etc.

subject: Submitting Project 1
content: Is the only form of submission that is required for the projects just uploading to autograder? So once we are happy with our files, our most recent autograder submission will be considered?. . Also, does each function need an RME before it? And will our stats_tests.cpp file be considered for any grading?
i_answer: Correct, you only need to submit/upload the required files to the autograder. We will grade passed on the highest scoring submit you make.. . You won't need to put an RME before each function you made (if you look at `stats.h`, we already did those for you!) And for `stats_tests.cpp`, we won't be grading directly on the tests/bugs you catch, but we want you to submit to see you wrote tests for your code.

subject: Is assert() required?
content: I’ve been using assert() for my test cases, but for some situations I feel like a more rudimentary approach is reliable.  Can I use other methods for determining if my test cases fail, or do I have to use assert() for this project?
i_answer: No, it is not required in p1.. . assert is helpful when it throws an exception to you. It is better than using cout to visually check differences.. . Specifically, I would say that both cout and assert are useful in specific circumstances. Assert is good in that it crashes the program when a test fails. However, it only tells you that your test failed. Cout can give you more detailed information about what is happening in the method. What I did was use cout to help fix my methods and asserts to create the tests.

subject: Magic Numbers
content: How strict will the style grade be on magic numbers? I have some numbers without variable names that I am using for calculations, do I have to create variable names for all of them?
i_answer: Numbers like -1, 1, 2, 3 are not magic numbers. You do not need to name them.. . Magic numbers like `INT_MAX`, `INT_MIN`, `DBL_MAX`, and `inf` are allowed in p1 because p1 will not be graded for style.. . However, magic numbers usually come with side effects - edge cases. For example, you want to find the min element, so you set your current element to `INT_MIN`. But what if the elements in that array are less than `INT_MIN`? If they are all `INT_MIN - 1`. Choose wisely, and think about is it necessary to use magic numbers?

subject: Auto type allowed for P1?

i_answer: Remember when you call functions you should not be putting the type of the variable in the function call. For example, you would call test_summarize(data) instead of test_summarize(vector<double> data). It's much easier to just create the data vector within the test function.

subject: Print summary data
content: Can somebody help me approach how to print the value: frequency pairs in main.cpp? I am thinking nested for loops but I'm having trouble conceptualizing how that would work with vectors within a vector.
i_answer: Treat it like a 2D array! You can index each element in the vector in the same way as you would in an array. For example: v[0][1] refers to the first vector's second element.

subject: what to put in stats_tests?

i_answer: To add onto this, you want to think of different data sets that could be considered "edge cases" for functions.

subject: Percentile 100
content: Hi, for my percentile, if I input the value for 100 as 0.99999 instead of 1.00 (or 1) it works, but 1.00 does not. would it be OK to use 0.9999 instead in main? or will this lose marks later on in the marking process?
i_answer: The 100th percentile is the last element in a dataset. You should not use 0.9999 for the input value of `p`. `p` is between 0 and 1, both inclusive.

subject: Frequency
content: Hi there, . . I'm having trouble going about finding the frequency of each value in the vector for the summarize and mode functions. . . I know I need to utilize a nested loop to iterate through the vector to compare each value with the rest in the vector, but I'm running into trouble such that after I iterate through the second loop to find the number of times that unique number occurs, I don't know how to effectively "skip" the rest of the duplicates in order to start counting the frequency of the next unique value. . . For example, with a vector = 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4. I understand how to compare i = 0 (1) with the rest of the vector, but how do I modify the loop such that I start counting from 2 (i = 3) instead of the next 1 (i = 1, since the loop is set up such that it increments by 1). Since there is no consistent pattern I am unsure as to how to "skip" the duplicates and start counting the frequency of the next unique value.. . If this doesn't make sense I can clarify!.
i_answer: in the first nested loop, you're comparing v[i] with whatever the number you're counting the frequency for is, right? are you asking how to start counting the next number in the vector? if so, set up your code so that if v[i] doesn't match the number you're counting, you take note of whatever data you need to take note of, and then set the number you're comparing to to the new number. at least in the method i used, i didn't need to use two nested for loops.

i_answer: `vector>` is not any different from `vector >` - it's just a choice of style. VSCode can be kinda annoying sometimes with giving false errors/taking a while to register changes. Restarting every now and then is good!

subject: Grading of Project 1
content: I am really confused on how Project 1 is graded. . What is the grade distribution for this project and does our stats_tests.cpp gets graded or is it just for us to find our own mistakes? Meaning if our code is running and we are happy with it do we have to do the stats_tests.cpp? Thank you!
i_answer: Your `stats.cpp` and `main.cpp` files will be the most substantial parts of your grade. The autograder runs both public & private tests against them (3 points will come from public tests and a number of points will be from private tests, released only after the deadline).. . While `stats_tests.cpp` is not graded for thoroughness **for P1 only**, it is a good idea to write quality test cases for the sake of running your own code against them to catch bugs. (Think about what types of private test cases we might be checking, and try to replicate them!). . For all future projects, we will be grading the quality of your test cases.

The autograder's feedback for P1 will include all the public tests you can see currently (3/3 if you passed them!) and a number of private tests that test your implementation.. . subject: I accidentally posted publicly then changed to private
content: Hi. I accidentally posted publicly a picture of my personal code (for the summarize function) and then immediately after realized (the post had 7 viewers) I changed it to a private post. I am so so tremendously sorry. What should I do or is that an immediate HC violation?
i_answer: Thanks for making the post private as soon as you noticed the mistake. While we consider it an honor code violation to share your code with others or make it publicly available, this is intended to apply for intentional sharing or prolonged public availability, such as through an online repository or schoolwork sharing website. We aren't going to report you for a mistaken post on Piazza.. . I don't expect anyone who saw the post will end up copying your code, but of course we can't control for that. If it were to happen, we'd make a report to the honor council based on a match between their submitted code and yours, but since we have a clear trail of how that could would have been obtained, my inclination would be to simply report that individual for taking advantage of another student who had accidentally, momentarily posted their code on Piazza.

subject: Erase() Function not working for vectors?
content: . Erase() function isn't working. Here is the error on the compiler. Not really sure what to do / how to fix this. Thanks for help!
i_answer: See: https://www.cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/erase/. . vector erase needs to know what position to erase starting from v.begin(). . So instead of v.erase(j), you would instead need v.erase(v.begin() + j).

i < v.size(); i++) {. if(num == v[i]){. return true;. }. }. return false;. }. . vector<std::vector<double> > summarize(std::vector<double> v){. double value;. vector <double> value_vector; //a vector to store values from v, only one instance of any value is stored here. vector <double> frequency_vector; //a vector just to store frequency of the values in the. vector<vector <double> > summary;. . for(int i = 0; i<v.size(); i++){ //creating the value_vector. value = v[i];. if (exist_in_vector(value_vector, value) == false){ //if a number from v doesn't exist in value_vector, that number will be appended. value_vector.push_back(value);. }. }. sort(value_vector); //sorting from least to greatest. . for(int i = 0; i<value_vector.size(); i++){ //creating a frequency vector. double frequency = 0; //frequency is set back to 0 after every loop. for (int j = 0; j<v.size(); j++){ //scans through the v vector. if (value_vector[i] == v[j]){ //if an element from value_vector is found in v, frequency will increment by 1. frequency++;. }. }. frequency_vector.push_back(frequency); //adds the final value of frequency to the vector. }. . for(int i = 0; i < value_vector.size(); i++){. //value_freq_vector will only have 2 elements: {value, frequency}. vector <double> value_freq_vector; //resets value_freq_vector after every loop. value_freq_vector.push_back(value_vector[i]); //appends ith element from value_vector. value_freq_vector.push_back(frequency_vector[i]); //appends ith elements from frequency_vector. summary.push_back(value_freq_vector); //{{value[0], frequency[0]}, {value[1], frequency[1]}, {value[2], frequency[2]}, ...}. }. return summary;. }. . int count(std::vector<double> v){. return v.size();. }. double sum(std::vector<double> v){. double total;. if(count(v)==0). {. return 0;. }. for(int i = 0; i < v.size(); i++). {. total += v[i];. }. return total;. }. double mean(std::vector<double> v){. if(count(v)==0). {. return 0;. }. else {. return sum(v) / count(v);. }. }. double median(std::vector<double> v){. sort(v);. if(count(v)==0). {. return 0;. }. if(count(v)%2==1). return v[(count(v)-1)/2];. else. return v[(((count(v)-1)/2) + ((count(v))/2)) / 2];. . }. double mode(std::vector<double> v){. sort(v);. if(count(v)==0). {. return 0;. }. int counter = 1;. int counter_temp = 0;. int temp_1 = v[0];. int final;. for(int i = 1; i<v.size(); i++). {. if(v[i]!=v[i-1]). {. if (counter > counter_temp){. counter_temp = counter;. final = v[i];}. }. else. {. counter++;. }. }. return final;. }. double min(std::vector<double> v){. sort(v);. return v[0];. }. double max(std::vector<double> v){. sort(v);. return v[count(v) - 1];. }. double stdev(std::vector<double> v){. if(v.size() < 2). {. return 0;. }. double u = mean(v);. double sum;. for(int i = 0; i<v.size();i++){. sum += pow ((v[i]-u), 2);. }. double omega_2 = sum / v.size();. double omega = pow(omega_2, 0.5);. return omega;. }. double percentile(std::vector<double> v, double p){. double percent = (p/100) * (count(v) - 1) + 1;. cout << p << "th percentile = " << percent;. return percent;. }. .

Additionally, there is a section in the spec that talks about signed and unsigned integer comparisons... it says if we use a for loop that looks like (int i; i < v.size(); i++), we'll run into a compile error. I have not had this issue when I run my program, should I still update the int i to type size_t?
i_answer: Yes you can increment an integer i by another variable in a for loop, but make sure that it gets the result you want - . ``` . vector example = {0,1,2,3}. for (size_t i = 0; i < v.size(); i++) {. cout << i << \n;. i += 1;. }. //will print out only 0 and 2. ```. . For the second one, have you compiled using `make clean` and then `make stats_tests.exe`? The flags that we set in that make shortcut should give you a compiler error

subject: Valgrind Error in main.cpp
content: While my code compiles just fine on its own, it has an error according to the autograder/Valgrind:. . . . What does this mean? I looked through the forums and I think @802 and @690 had the same problem, but there didn't seem to be a clear resolution. I understand that this means "index out of bounds", but I don't know how that applies to my percentile method.. . If the code runs through VSCode without errors, why does Valgrind find an error?
i_answer: Step through your percentile() function and check anywhere you have v.at(…) or v[…]. Try and find out if it ever tries to access an index that is out of bounds. For example, in the small_data_set test provided, the size would be 3 (so the possible indices would be 0, 1, and 2).You probably have something like v.at(k + 1) or v[k + 1] and if the index k + 1 is greater than 2 (or less than 0), you’re trying to access an invalid index.

subject: Static_cast vs size_t
content: Is there a difference if I use static_cast<int> instead of using size_t? I saw in the project slides from the supplemental instruction that we should be using size_t but I already cast the v.size() to int throughout. Will this make a difference in the autograder?
i_answer: It doesn't matter for this problem.. . ```. size_t x = v.size(); //size_t -> size_t | ok. int x = static_cast(v.size()); // int -> (int) | ok. int x = v.size(); //int -> size_t | problem. ```. There will be an overflow for sure. But you need an array with the size of 8GB to cause this overflow. It is an extremely unusual case for this project.. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-17_at_21.17.10.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F95789219ecc86bef12f5cd8360c005b977d81517093acc190345a9c12456a03d%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-17_at_21.17.10.png)

subject: Is there a way I can see what the vector of vectors that summarize creates actually is?
content: I created an assert statement that is failing in my test case, but how do I see what the summarize function is creating in order to debug this?
i_answer: You can split your `assert` and then use debugger to run your code line by line. For example:. . ```c++. std::vector vec{1,2,3};. . // Original code. assert(foo(vec) == something);. . // Split it to. std::vector output = foo(vec); // Step into here, or set a debugger at the entry of your foo(). assert(output == something);. . ```

subject: Repreated include statements
content: Will there be a problem if I include the same "#include <   >" statements in stats.cpp, stats_tests.cpp, and main.cpp? I think one of the lectures said to be wary of repeating the inclusion of .h libraries but I don't remember what it said about <> ones.
i_answer: No. All included files are controlled by `macro` conditional statement. You will see something like . . ```c++. #ifndef _LIBCPP_VECTOR // if not defined. #define _LIBCPP_VECTOR // then define, otherwise, do not define again. ```. . So, your compiler will not define the same functions from the same header file twice.

subject: Outputting doubles instead of ints
content: Ive been submitting to the autograder and my code is outputting doubles with lots of 0s instead of ints (i.e) 6.000000 instead of 6, and my standard deviation is one decimal point more accurate for some reason. How can I format this correctly without hard coding int casting because I dont want to blindly force every double into an int. thanks!
i_answer: DId you set up `cout.precision()` at the very beginning of your program? If you did, remove that line.. . If you did not set the precision manually. Your program has some problems. Although `std::cout` has the default precision of 6 significant digits, it will cut off remaining zeros if the number is a perfect integer/decimals. It is unlikely that the default `cout` configuration will cause a problem.

subject: How to approach the function summarize() ?
content: I have an idea about getting the vector{value, times of appearance}, but I'm not sure what the next step is. How should I make a vector of vectors? Is it bigVector.push_back(smallVector1), bigVector.push_back(smallVector2)....? and should I make it vertical like the RME shows? or it can be like {{1,1}, {1,2}, {2,2}.....}
i_answer: To make a vector of vectors you need to create a 2-D vector using vector<vector<double>>. You can then use 2Dvector.push_back(1Dvector) to add the vectors with value and times of appearance. The vector does not need to be vertical and you can just keep pushing back the 2-D vector. You should create the new vector before adding it to the 2-D vector and can continuously make a new vector using a for loop. Make sure you are accounting for multiple vectors being made for the same number and for the last value in the vector. FYI, you can also do:. . double x, y;. v.push_back({x,y});

However, to prevent running into this same problem again, I'd recommend running your program from the terminal. It's less time consuming and much simpler once you start using it more frequently.

subject: percentile
content: If there is only one element in the vector, will the percentile function return 1?
i_answer: Look at appendix A of the spec again. The percentile is tied to the range of the input.. . $$P_{rank} = \frac{p}{100}(N - 1) + 1$$. $$P_{rank} = \frac{p}{100}(1 - 1) + 1 = 1$$The 'rank' calculator would have to return 1 (N = 1), but not (necessarily) the whole percentile function.. Just find $$v_p$$ from there.

subject: Valgrind and normal testing
content: When I tested my main program on the terminal (without Valgrind), it worked perfectly fine and had no problems while compiling and running, however, when I tested my program with Valgrind, I a very large amount of error, what is the reason behind that and more importantly, The error messages in Valgrind is not clear so how can I find out what is the actual problem?
i_answer: When you compile and run your code on CAEN, you might see additional errors since the compiler settings (and some others) on CAEN are often stricter than those in your personal computer's IDE. This is why we suggest that you run your code on CAEN before submitting as the settings on CAEN match those on the autograder. . . Valgrind is a code/runtime analysis tool that is available on the CAEN computers. Valgrind will show you all possible memory errors, which include ones that your test cases might not have exposed. This is why your code might look like it runs without a problem on your computer, but still might have a glaring bug, such as indexing out of bounds on a vector.. . Can you post the error message from valgrind? We can translate it together to give you some debugging intuition for the future.

subject: Number of decimals for stdev
content: How many decimal places should we print for stdev and should we be rounding up at the end. For the numbers {6, 7, 8, 9, 10} the actual value is 1.5811388300841898 but on the specs it is printed as 1.58114. What is specifically the correct way to print out the number to the correct length and accuracy. It seems to change in different situations.
i_answer: it should automatically print out the designated number of significant figures. you don't have to worry about that unless there's a rounding error, which, then, you should use the epsilon constant found in the appendix to see if the actual and calculated have a difference less than the value of epsilon

subject: for loop format
content: In c++ does a for loop always need to have three variables. For example, can the update/iterator that typically goes at the end need to be included within the parenthesis of the for loop or can it be omitted if you want to update your variable in a different part of your code. For instance, is.  for(int i = 0; i < max;){. //some code. } valid?
i_answer: No, you can have 0 entries. Like this. . ```c++. for (;;) {} // Valid, an infinite loop. ```. . If you declared `i` and the loop depends on `i` to execute. You must update `i` in the loop. Otherwise, there will be a warning (depending on your configurations). It does not matter where you update it.

subject: Variables for Tests Cases
content: Do we need to use meaningful variable names for the vectors we create for test cases? Or is it okay if we just call them data1, data2, etc.?
i_answer: You can call them whatever you want, but it's usually better to always have variables with meaningful names for your own benefit. That way if you write some code and then look at it a few days later, you'll immediately know what your variables are representing, instead of having to read multiple lines to figure out where and how each variable is used.

subject: Floating point comparisons in private test cases
content: Will the private test cases check if values satisfy (abs(x - y) < epsilon) or will they just check if the rounded value is correct? For example, if "119.73840286223965" is the output and "119.738" is the answer, the output rounds correctly, but abs(x - y) would be 0.0004, which is not less than epsilon. Would that be incorrect?
i_answer: Yes, the actual precision of `double` is at least 16 significant digits. Frankly, $$1E-5$$ is a very generous epsilon. If the difference is greater than the epsilon, it means your algorithm might be buggy. Or, your expected output is not precise enough. For example, $$\frac{1}{3} = 1.333333333333...$$, but you only round to $$1.33$$.

i_answer: Having a valgrind error could result in failing private tests. You will still have the 3 points you got on the AG, but you may lose points when the private tests are run.

subject: Running on CAEN

Still, it is running an older version of my file and I wasn't quite sure what I did wrong!
i_answer: Make sure to rsync all of your files to CAEN.

subject: Project 1 error

Also, I'm fairly sure that you do not have to include the double(3.5) and could leave it as just 3.5; it already is a floating-point/double value.. . See FAQ @11 and @277

subject: Input redirection

i_answer: I would recommend running this in your visual debugger, because generally segmentation faults mean that your program crashed because it accessed invalid memory. The error message shown here is not helpful at all (where did it crash? Who knows!), but if you pull it up in the debugger it can usually show you where exactly the crash happened!

subject: Valgrind Not Asking For User Input
content: When I run Valgrind on main.exe on CAEN Linux, it is not prompting me to enter the filename or column name from stdin. However, when I run ./main.exe on its own, it prompts me for the user input on its own on CAEN Linux. Is there any reason Valgrind would not be asking for user input, and how can I fix this issue? . .
i_answer: It looks like this is a known problem with mixing address sanitizers and valgrind. If you completed the address sanitizer part of the mega-tutorial, you'll have to undo your changes if you would like valgrind to run normally. (Also address sanitizers don't work well on CAEN anyway).

subject: Not many edge cases
content: I’ve implemented all of the obvious edge cases I could think of, but some functions like min(), max(), count(), etc. and even mean() don’t seem to have many possible edge cases.I’ve gone through all of the possible inputs that I can think of and my functions should be able to handle all of them fine. I’m just worried because it feels like I’m not writing enough edge cases, but there just don’t seem to be many for a lot of my functions.Anyone else having this problem?
i_answer: Not all functions will have edge cases. It's normal to feel like you haven't tested thoroughly, since you have no way of knowing if you've captured every potential input. Be as creative as possible! If you feel stuck, scroll through posts on Piazza for inspiration or go to OH and discuss with an IA. If you are getting 3/3 on the AG, I'd say you are off to a good start.

subject: If our code runs and compiles and receive 3/3 on autograder, is it necessary that it run on CAEN?
content: I am still having trouble setting up CAEN and want to know if it will make a difference for project 1 in this scenario.
i_answer: The AG runs on CAEN, so in this sense it won't be necessary to run your code on CAEN. However, be aware that there are private test cases, and since the AG runs on CAEN it would be in your best interest to test your code thoroughly on CAEN. There can be subtle differences between the way things run in your IDE/your local setup vs. how they run on CAEN, so we always advise getting CAEN setup and running your code frequently there.

subject: What value percentile() should return
content: I'm a bit confused about what exactly the percentile function is supposed to return. The RME in stats.h says it returns the percentile p of the numbers in v, but then we also pass in a variable called p to the function. Is the percentile p that we're returning from the function v_p in the Excel equation provided? Also, since percentile() only returns a double, do we just call it 5 times in main? And are we assuming that we're always just going to be finding the 0th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 100th percentile?
i_answer: vp, which is what is returned by percentile,is simply the p-th percentile. The results of your program should match the example shown here in the spec, so it's ok to assume you'll just be finding the 0th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 100th percentile. However, it is good practice (and will also make your coding easier) to write your implementation so that it can handle any value of p.

subject: main.cpp
content: hello, . I was working on main.cpp and wasn't sure if my approach was correct for how to call extract_column? Also when I run main.cpp in the terminal window I get error: no matching function for call to 'summarize' including all the functions I implemented. What files should be included in main.cpp?. .
i_answer: This is the function declaration for extract_column in p1_library.h:. . std::vector<double> extract_column(std::string filename, std::string column_name);. std::vector<double> indicates the return type. The function takes in 2 strings: a filename and a column name. Based on this info, revise how you call extract_column on line 22.. . Here is the function declaration for summarize, in stats.h:. . std::vector<std::vector<double> > summarize(std::vector<double> v);. . summarize should be called on a vector of doubles but on line 23, it's being called on a double. Your included libraries look good, so the error shows up because there isn't a function called summarize that takes in a double. . .

subject: test cases
content: I had a question regarding how to write test cases for summarize function.
i_answer: For summarize, you need to write a vector that is your test input, and a vector that is your answer. Then you can just use the equivalence operator as normal since it can be overloaded for vectors. First it checks if they are the same size, then it checks if each element is the same.

To do that, do I just login to CAEN and then run the same commands I did to test my code when I wasn’t in CAEN? Or do I have to run the tests on CAEN using a different command?
i_answer: You can test the same way. You can also run stuff such as make style, or check the mega setup for things like valgrind.. .

subject: data.push_back
content: Hi,. I don't really understand when to use the data.push_back function.. What's the difference of using data.push_back and just assigning the data to a variable?. . vector data;.   data.push_back(1);.   data.push_back(2);.   data.push_back(3);. . vector data;.   data = {1, 2, 3}
i_answer: No huge difference. The second one is to call the copy constructor, but the first method is to `push_back` new element to an empty vector. They are equivalent for the purpose of creating a vector with some elements. However, the second method is a shortcut.

subject: Mean Edge Case
content: For my mean() function, I just divide sum() by count(). However, the RME for count() doesn’t say that it cannot be empty, so I could end up with a divide by 0 error and crash my program.I am unsure of how to go about testing for this while still passing the test.Could I just check if count() returns 0, and if it does, print a message out to the user saying the answer is undefined/DNE because the mean of an empty set is undefined/DNE. Although, I can’t really assert() anything using this method and “passing” this test would just be printing out a message and continuing on with the program.Is there a better way to go about this?
i_answer: Hmmm. Yes, the RME for `count()` does not say if the vector can be empty or not. But the RME for `mean()` says the input cannot be empty. So, it is impossible to cause a divided by zero problem when following RME.

content: I read over all the posts about testing percentile with 1 value and analyzed the formula in the appendix. From my thinking, any percentile calculated based off a list that only has 1 value such as {15} or {1} should be 0 because there are no values below or above this value. Is my understanding correct?

I think it is reasonable to think for example, if a school only has one student, no matter how the student performs in exams, the percentile from 0 to 100% (in terms of grades) should only consider this student's grade.

subject: Trouble Running Multiple Files
content: When doing the stats project I coded without the use of header files and only did it in one test.cpp file that's located in a separate directory. For this file I just assumed that my program was able to read the main_test_data.tsv file, so I created a vector "extractedColumn" that's supposed to represent the vector returned from the extract_column function, containing {6, 7, 8, 9, 10}. All the code in this one file was able to work just fine, but now I'm having trouble transferring all of this into multiple files.. . I placed my function definitions into stats.cpp and my main code is in main.cpp. I did not edit any of the provided code.. . When I ctrl + f5 in VS studio (compile and run shortcut) I get this message:. . . When entering in the command into the terminal to create a main.exe I got this message:.
i_answer: It looks like there are a few different issues:. 1. In the first screenshot, it says "main already defined" which suggests you're trying to compile multiple files, where two or more of them contain a `main()` function. See https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_visualstudio.html#compile-with-visual-studio and post @480 to understand how to set your compile sources appropriately for each program. 2. In the second screenshot, you're trying to use the `count()` function to get the frequency of an element in the vector - this method comes from the `` library, which can't be used for this project. 3. Also in the second screenshot, see this section of the spec to fix the error with comparing `n > v.size() - 1`: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#signed-and-unsigned-integer-comparisons

subject: Clarification on Function Running by Itself
content: Hello, quick clarification question.. When the lecture says that they want the "function to run by itself" does that still mean that we can call other functions we created inside of a given function. An example of this is my stdev() function calling upon the mean() function. Is this still allowed or do I need to recreate the calculation of finding the mean in the stdev() function?. Thanks in advance.
i_answer: Yes, you can still do that since the project asks us to implement all of these functions in the stats library. Abstraction is encouraged!

subject: Question P - 1
content: Hi, I am not able to figure this out... could you please give me a hint?. . . . I did what is shown in line 82 for the odd numbers that are in the data... I'm not sure if this is correct, or not for what is written in line 78, for the even numbers in the data. Please help me!
i_answer: I think its always helpful to have a few examples that are small enough to step through your code by hand. Try stepping through your median implementation with two vectors, with an even and odd size, and keep in mind what your expected median should be. I would also write the indices for these vectors too. . For example, here's a vector with an odd number of elements: `[1, 2, 3]` - what should the median be for this? Take a look at the index values too - your implementation says the median should be at index `v.size() - 1 / 2` - does that line up with the expected median?. . Then consider an even number of elements, like `[1, 2, 3, 4]` - what's the median here? How do we calculate a median when there's an even number of elements, and will it be at index `v.size() - 1 / 3`?. . Answering these questions should help you with your implementation!

subject: Question about type casting
content: . . In function count, v.size() is size_t type while countValue is init as "int". In this case, do we need to convert v.size() to int manually? There is no compiling error in Autograder system no matter adding type conversion or not.. . There is an alarm in Xcode but no alarm in Visual Studio Code (I use g++ compiler). So I am afraid whether or not my compiler
i_answer: For good practice, you should always **explicitly** cast a type, especially when there is a potential casting overflow. `size_t` is an `uint64_t`, which is longer than `int` which is an `int32_t`. It is possible that this implicit conversion will cause type overflow.. . Because this is not an ISO C++ specified warning, different compilers may have different tolerance of implicit casting. For example, g++ generally reports more warnings than clang++.. . Also, my suggestion is not to use **C-style cast**. It has been deprecated by ISO C++11. The reason that you can still use it is because of the backward compatibility. So, instead of using `(int)`, you can use `static_cast(size_t)`.

subject: summarize function error
content: here's my code. not sure why there's an error. . . void testSummarize() {. cout << "testSummarize" << endl;. . vector<double> data;. data.push_back(2.84);. data.push_back(2.84);. data.push_back(0);. data.push_back(100.7);. data.push_back(7);. data.push_back(-62.8);. . vector<vector<double> > temp = {{-62.8, 1},{0,1},{2.84,2},{7,1},{100.7,1}};. . assert(summarize(data) == temp);. . cout << "PASS!" << endl;. . }. . . .

But if the assertion failed, you may want to check your ```summarize``` function like putting a break point inside the function and compare the generated ```vector of vectors of doubles``` is the same as your ```temp```.

subject: Are we allowed to make #include additions to the top of our files?
content: For instance, can I add #include "p1_library.h" to the top of stats.cpp
i_answer: Yes!. . Just make sure you follow the restrictions https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#tips-tricks-and-restrictions.

subject: Interpreting Valgrind Output
content: How do I read the errors it is giving me here?
i_answer: Invalid read of size 6 generally means you're going out of bounds somewhere. I know it seems like a ton of words got outputted, but I like to focus on the line numbers and function names I recognize - if you look at the two lines under "invalid read of size 6", you'll notice that the error is happening somewhere in the mode function, in the file stats.cpp at line 142. And then underneath it, mode was called from main.cpp in line 65. Hopefully this helps you narrow down where the problem is!

subject: I feel like my .size() is returning value of a strange type, and everything is not working
i_answer: In your loop, the variable "i" is of type integer, whereas the type returned by "v.size()" is of type "size_type", which is where your error is coming from. You can remedy this by either casting your .size call to an integer, or instantiating 'i' as a size_t, instead of an int.

subject: Function Running by Itself
content: In lecture it said the functions must work when run by themselves, does that mean they have to print by themselves?. For context in main.cpp I have. cout << "whatever = " << function(v) << endl;. instead of having something similar within the functions
i_answer: No. The way you have it is correct. The RME for the stats function would specify that something should be printed if that was a requirement.. . Edit:. To clarify what "functions must work when run by themselves" means, lets say you implement a function fun(v) that requires v is not empty. Then in main you call it with:. . . vector<double> v{3,2,1};. sort(v);. fun(v);. Let's say this works. However, what if someone else calls your function and doesn't sort v? Your function still needs to work correctly since v being sorted is not a requirement for your function.

subject: How can I use the sort function here?? I feel like "library.h" is not included anywhere
i_answer: Please try to use the search function on Piazza before posting a question. You may find other students have the same questions and they've already been answered.

subject: Percentile: p: [0, 1] or p: [0, 100]?
content: Hello,. I'm very confused because my code works and has the correct output for my test cases, main_test_data, and the real data from the research, but in my percentile function, I'm accounting for p: [0, 100] like in the wiki screenshot in the spec for percentile. However, stats.h requires that p: [0, 1]. Should I divide all my 'double p' inputs and multiply by 100 in my percentile function?. . best,. . Jenna
i_answer: The function must take p: [0,1] as you said. You could technically multiply by p by 100 in your function so that your implementation of the Wikipedia equation still works. Though, something to consider is that you would basically be doing this:. . $$\frac{p\cdot100}{100}$$

subject: empty() method seems not contained in allowed libraries
content: I used expression "!empty(v)" to check if vector is empty. However, the use of this function will cause error. 'empty'  is  not  declared  in  this  scope. when the command line below is executed:. g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic --std=c++11 -g main.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o main.exe. . I wonder if this should be the case..
i_answer: I think the syntax should be !v.empty()

subject: Test case limit
content: Is there a limit to the number of test cases we're allowed to have in Project 1 or in future projects?
i_answer: Not for this project, but I believe in project 2 we will be limited to 50 tests per file. Generally, it is a good idea to not write too many tests. Tests should not be redundant with each other - typically you want one general test and one test for each interesting edge case.

subject: Formatting for median
content: Since the median function would return two doubles for vectors with even numbers, what is the formatting for how it is returned? Would it be 3, 4 or {3, 4} or 3 4 ... etc
i_answer: The median function has to return a single double, as this is how the function is declared in the stats.h. If the vector has an even number of elements, you need to average the two middle elements.

subject: Post testing
content: I have finished testing the stats_tests.exe. I looked into the spec but I didn't really understand what to do after doing the testing?
i_answer: I am a little unclear about what you're asking about here, but if you have successfully tested your code against the public test cases, I would recommend coming up with some of your own test cases that consider edge cases for each of the functions. You can also submit your .cpp files to the autograder to confirm that you are still passing the public test cases in that context.

subject: Sort Function
content: I am getting an error related to the sort function when I try to compile.. "undefined reference to `sort(std::vector<double, std::allocator<double> >&)'collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status". I've read through a few posts about the sort function but I still don't really understand it. In my code I put sort(v) with v being a vector of doubles.
i_answer: Did you make sure to #include "p1_library.h" at the top of your file? The compiler will not know what the sort function is if you don't do this since the function declaration is in p1_library.h.

subject: mean function fails public tests on autograder but passes on my computer

What could be causing this/ how can I fix this? Thank you!.
i_answer: try setting your variable totalSum = 0 when you declare it in your mean function.  sometimes when you add something to an uninitialized variable, while it may behave as if it was default set to 0 on your computer, other times (specifically in the autograder) it can take on the value of some random garbage and cause your number to become super big/small.

subject: stdev test
content: I was trying to test stdev with assert(stdev(v) == n), however, since some time the stdev has infinite decimal(eg. 0.03^(1/2), but xcode failed to run this). Then when I use assert, what value shall I write in order to stand for the accurate value?
i_answer: Check the specs. What you can do assert (abs(stdev(v) - answer) < 0.0001). . That just means that if the return value of stdev is the same as the answer by 4 decimal places, then this will return true.. . You always have to compare floating point numbers in this way, since as you stated they can have many decimal places and may not be 100% accurate to very small decimal places.

subject: Mean comparison above epsilon

subject: Frequency

That way, you don't have to worry as much about skipping around in the vector or re-counting a value that you already counted.

subject: input redirection
content: What is the purpose of input redirection? I have read about it in the spec but am confused as to what its purpose is for us. I was able to complete the steps in the terminal correctly for input redirection for the main_test.in file. But, when I continued to the next step of going into my IDE (visual studio) and clicked properties to change the command argument main.cpp would no longer compile. It caused the Visual Studio black window to pop up for input and then disappear really quickly. It flickered off like there were too many files with main being compiled at once (I definitely checked and only 1 file with main() was included in the build). Do we have to use the input redirection in our IDE? What is its purpose?
i_answer: Before input redirection, you could only interact with your program by typing in the inputs by hand. While you can test your program this way, running through a lot of test cases becomes quite tedious, as they have to be entered manually. By feeding predetermined inputs from input files to the program, input redirection eliminates the need to manually interact with your program, automating the execution of test cases. After you set up input redirection in Visual Studio, your code still compiled and ran, but the output window disappeared immediately because your program read the inputs from your input file, printed the results, and then finished immediately.. . This technique could be outdated, but try pressing "Ctrl+F5" to run your program. Visual Studio has a default "press any key to continue" behavior for console applications that should be invoked through this key combination (at least, >10 years ago). Alternatively, you can adjust the command-line arguments in Visual Studio for _output redirection_ like ` output.txt`, which would make your program write its output to `output.txt` in its working directory.

subject: Percentile function - updating to index 0
content: I was looking through the piazza posts and saw that the rank formula should be changed to not include the + 1 at the end but was confused as to why that is the case. I changed the second formula - . so that it indexes from 0 rather than 1. So do I need to change both parts of the formula?
i_answer: You can change either formula, but one and only one. Conceptually, the lowest index value will occur when p = 0, and in that case, the lowest rank will be 1. . So you don't + 1 at the end of the first formula, that way, the lowest value is just p = 1. This also accounts for the max value as well technically, since if P = 1, then it would just be (size - 1) as your index. . . If you change both parts of your formula, it's like you're now subtracting by 2, (because in the second formula to re-index you would need to subtract 1 from k.

subject: Output Summary
content: What error could be occurring if my summarize function will not output anything. Should the function be building a summary vector itself, or be outputting the vectors as it goes? I assume the former, but in stats_public_test, calling summary(v) doesn't output anything, even though it is supposed to return the vector of vectors. Not sure if there is something wrong in my code or in the way I use it.
i_answer: Summary returns a vector of vectors, so it's not supposed to output anything. You can check the RME.. . The point of stats_public_tests.exe isn't to actually output useful values for the functions, it's a regression test to see if your code actually compiles. They just call summarize to see if you don't have any issues. The reason they count the other functions returns values is that they actually return values and that's something to check for (if nothing returns there would be an error etc, well tbh it would be an error when compiling).

subject: duplicate symbol
content: What does  this "duplicate symbol" mean?
i_answer: This means that you have >1 .cpp files in your build that have main methods (hence “duplicate”). The main method acts as an entry point to the execution of your program. By having >1, the program doesn’t know where to start.. . To ensure there is only 1 main method (another name for function), click on a .cpp file in your XCode file explorer and ensure that the “Target Membership” checkbox on the right side is checked for only the files you want to include in your build. Only 1 of these files can have a main method.

subject: Summarize function
content: For the result we should return. Can I push back like. vec.push_back(vector<double>(v[i], frequency))?
i_answer: Check out the third constructor overload for `std::vector` from [cppreference](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container/vector/vector). Your code will probably invoke this constructor (`std::vector::vector(size_type count, T& value)`), which would create a `vector` with `v[i]` elements where each element is a copy of `frequency`. For instance, if you want to record that $$3$$ showed up $$4$$ times, calling `vector(3, 4)` would give you $$[4, 4, 4]$$. As the student answer states, you would want to use curly braces instead, like `vector{v[i], frequency}`. In this instance, that call would create $$[3, 4]$$ instead.

subject: Error when running stats_tests.cpp
content: I am using VS Code on a mac with an m1 chip. Whenever I try running stats_tests.cpp I get an error. So far I've been debugging by with .\stats_tests.exe instead because my output shows up fine in the terminal, but I don't know if this error indicates that my setup is wrong. This is the error I get when I click the "run" button and try to compile:. . . Undefined symbols for architecture arm64:. "max(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. "min(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. "sum(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. test_sum_small_data_set() in stats_tests-66126a.o. "mean(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. "mode(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. "count(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. "stdev(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. "median(std::__1::vector<double, std::__1::allocator<double> >)", referenced from:. _main in stats_tests-66126a.o. ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture arm64. clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation).
i_answer: Resolved in OH.. . If you are using the CodeRunner extension in VS Code, you have to configure the compilation commands yourself for the "Run" button to work. I'll provide some notes for how to do this for P1 below.. . 1. Open the command palette (Windows: Ctrl + Shift + P).. 2. Type "open settings".. 3. Choose the "Open Settings (JSON)" option (picture below).. . 4. Append the following key to the settings.json file (note that this might not have all the compilation flags and there is no file input redirection here - you would need to add that to the command):. .     "code-runner.executorMapByGlob": {.         "stats_tests.cpp": "g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 $fileName stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe && ./stats_tests.exe",.         "stats_public_test.cpp": "g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 $fileName stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_public_test.exe && ./stats_public_test.exe",.         "main.cpp": "g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 $fileName stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o main.exe && ./main.exe",.         "*": "echo \"$fileName: Non-executable file\"",.     }. 5. (Optional) If you want the output to show up in the Terminal tab in VS Code instead of the Output tab, add the following key as well:. . "code-runner.runInTerminal": true. . Hope this helps!

subject: How many individual tests (asserts) appropriate for a test function
content: In my stats tests file, I've made a couple test functions that create different vectors and check that my stats functions output the expected values. In my functions, I test multiple of my stats functions (e.g. percentile, mean, count, etc.) in each function when I create a data set, whereas I've seen in the lectures only one stats function being tested in each testing function. Is there an appropriate amount of stats functions I should be testing in each testing function?
i_answer: There's not really a "right" number of test cases for all functions.  It depends on the function (i.e. count() will probably have fewer test cases than stdev()) and on your own creativity.  Try to think of 1) all the possible mistakes you might have made in your function that could cause bugs and write test cases for these and 2) weird (that is, edge) cases that could cause problems (think the extremes of percentile()).

subject: summarize() Function Stopping Midway

i_answer: To debug it, set a break point at the beginning of your summarize() function and step through the function.  Your function is probably returning its value earlier than you want it to if its stopping half-way through.  A breakpoint at the beginning of summarize() will help you find where.

If it helps you to have it in the same file, you could copy-paste it into the .cpp file while you're implementing the functions and delete it afterwards :)

subject: use of sqrt()
content: When I use the sqrt() function in cmath and print out cout << sqrt(2/3), the output is 0. How does sqrt() behave?
i_answer: Sqrt is a function that takes in some numerical type and then returns the square root of the argument. When you write sqrt(2/3), you can think of it as calling the sqrt function with the value of the expression (2/3). The expression 2/3 is doing integer division, because it’s dividing 2 integers, and integer division always “truncates” the decimal value. You can think of it as always “rounding down” no matter what the decimal value is. So for example, the expression (9/10) evaluates to 0.9 which gets rounded down to 0.

subject: Able to use helper functions in stats.cpp?
content: Hi!. . I noticed that most of the vectors passed into the stats library are doubles. Some of the functions I coded requires to check two doubles are equal. I wrote a helper function to check that. I was wondering if I am able to do that in project 1.. . Thanks,. Zihao
i_answer: Use epsilon, and compare double values up to a significant figure. For example, for function mean, to compare double values, when assert( test == actual), might be wrong because test = 3.44444400000067 and actual = 3.44444400000043. So by using epsilon = 10^-6 or some small value, you can do assert (abs(test - actual) < epsilon) instead so that the difference of the two would be below the threshold.

subject: printing vector
content: How do we print the vector of summaries so that it looks like the expected output given in main “value : frequency” How can i first print the value, add a colon, then print frequency? if we do cout << v[i][j] let’s say i and j are before zero will it print the first value of the first vector only? meaning it’ll only print the first vector without its frequency then if we do v[0][1] it will print the frequency of the first vector? Or will v[i][j] print out the entire subvector like printing two numbers at once (the value and frequency)?
i_answer: Normally, to print a vector, you would use a loop to loop through each value. Since it’s a vector of vectors, you’ll need a nested for loop.Try just printing out v[0][0], v[0][1], v[1][0], v[1][1] etc. and see what values correspond to those. That might help you visualize it a little better.

subject: vector value optimized out
content: I am trying to pass a vector into the summarize function from stats_tests.cpp to stats.cpp, but the vector does not carry over. The description reads:. . (std::vector<double, std::allocator<double> >) v = <no location, value may have been optimized out>. . I am not quite sure what may be causing the vector to not translate over. Does anyone have any ideas as to why this may be? . . I have tried to pass the same vector listed in "Appendix B: vector How to" but no luck!. . Thank you!. .
i_answer: I am not quite sure about your compiler flags. Did you enable `-Ox` instead of `-g`? If you see this in your debugger even you enabled `-g`. I do not think there is a way to show that temporary variable, I am not sure if `-g3` can show more information. But you can have a try. Following are more details.. . It is an enforced optimization in **C++17**. The standard enforces compiler to optimize `A x = A()`. The reason for this is to optimize the usage of temporary variables. In traditional C++, i.e. C++98, this seemly unharmful assignment operation will cause performance issues. It is what C++ was criticized for before the **Modern C++**, starting from C++11.. . In C++11, this assignment operation can be optimized. Though it is not enforced by C++11, some newer versions of compilers will enforce this particular C++17 mandatory rule even you enable `-std=c++11`, since it is completely optional according to C++11. . . `A x = A()` will call the constructor once and the copy constructor once, which is a meaningless copy, and the meaningless deconstructor once. After the optimization, additional copy operations will be omitted.. . . . Instead of reading the secondary source, here is the ISO C++11 standard, **§12.8.31**. > \- when a temporary class object that has not been bound to a reference (12.2) would be copied/moved to a class object with the same cv-unqualified type, the copy/move operation can be omitted by constructing the temporary object directly into the target of the omitted copy/move

So you will need to initialize a vector variable and then compare with that.. . https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/list_initialization. . Example:. . . vector<double> data = /* something */;. vector<vector<double>> correct{{1,1},{2,1}};. assert(summarize(data) == correct);

subject: Tests
content: What structure are we supposed to follow when writing test cases?. For example, is this allowed/encouraged/requested? (just an example, I know my syntax isn't fully correct):. . main{. 	testingFunction1(function1ParamtersForFirstEdgeCase, intendedAnswer); . 			//intended answer is what function1 is supposed to return, if working correctly. 	testingFunction1(function1ParamtersForSecondEdgeCase, intendedAnswer);. }. testingFunction1(function1ParamtersForXthEdgeCase, intendedAnswer){. 	varType answer=Function1(function1ParamtersForXthEdgeCase);. 	assert(answer==intendedAnswer);. }. Or like are we supposed to having a testing function for each edge case we want to test? Or something else? Thanks
i_answer: This isn’t necessarily incorrect, but the structure we recommend for this project is this:void functionname(); //prototypeint main(){    functionname();    // other test cases functions}void functionname(){    //test case here}In future projects, we’ll introduce a better testing framework to use.

subject: Declaring functions in scope
content: For the stats_tests.cpp file, I noticed that we need to declare all of the functions we're creating above the main function. Why would we not just write the functions out in that space to save needing to declare them twice?
i_answer: Since our `main()` function comes _before_ the actual declaration/implementation of our test functions, the compiler isn't able to identify all these functions when we're trying to run them in main. So, we end up having to declare everything at the top of our file, before `main()` to prevent this error. (In stats.cpp we solve this issue by declaring our functions in the stats.h file!)

subject: Number of Tests and Tests Clarification

For test cases, the idea is to cover all potential bugs that a user could reasonably make, so create a variety of tests according to your interpretation of this.. subject: Function Prototype
content: What is a function prototype versus the actual function, they are told to be in different spots in the provided code files.
i_answer: Function prototype or declaration:double mean(std::vector <double> v);Function definition (“actual” function):double mean(std::vector <double> v){    // code would go here that actually DOES stuff}So the prototype includes a return type (double in my example), a name (mean), and a (possibly empty) parameter list (v). While the “actual” function has all of that AND code to do stuff in between the curly braces.You might be familiar with seeing it all included at once with no separation between the declaration and definition. It’s the same thing, but this allows us to separate interface and implementation.Basically, the prototype declares or says “this thing exists”The actual implementation actually does the stuff.For example, we don’t need to know exactly how the sort() function we are provided with works (implementation). We only need to know how to use the function and what values we can pass in (interface). So, rather than knowing the sorting algorithm, we just write sort(v); and it sorts it for us.We generally put the prototypes (declarations) in header (.h) files and the definitions in .cpp files and include the header file in the .cpp file.Again, this is super important to accomplish abstraction. In Professor Juett’s PB&J example. We don’t need to know how to create peanut butter or jelly or bread, we just need to know how to combine them to make a PB&J. Also, whether you realize it or not, we’re already using TONS of abstraction to write the programs we do. We can use a computer and have no clue how computers even came to be or what magic goes on inside them. So abstraction is really important in most academic disciplines, especially computer science.Hope this helps!

i_answer: I think you have a typo in your remote URL! Your uniqname is `abiduke`, but your HTTP url has `abiuke/p1-stats.git`.. . To fix this, you should reset your origin:. 1. Run `git remote remove origin` to remove the current origin. 2. Run `git remote add origin ...` replacing ... with the correct gitlab HTTP url - if you go to your gitlab repo and click on the blue 'Clone' button, you should be able to copy the correct url there!

i_answer: Yes, the test cases will be graded. . . From the spec: . "We will grade your code on functional correctness and the presence of test cases.". . Additionally, you should test your code thoroughly to ensure that it will be able to pass the private test cases not shown on the Autograder and that it works correctly.

subject: interpreting error message
content: What does this error message mean in the autograder? How do I fix it? .
i_answer: This error is a result of a lack of return value on a function that requires it. Usually this is because of a conditional return statement that is never being reached. To solve this, guarantee that you are returning something at the end of your function.. . This error doesn't show up on your local computer because the autograder has different configurations and looks for different things. Make sure you run your code on CAEN to check these warnings before submitting to the autograder.

subject: 2d vector type
content: So for each pair in 2d vector, the first number in the pair is the value(which is double), and the second number in the pair is the count(which is int). . . I declared the 2d vector as double, but when I push back the count into the 2d vector I got "invalid narrowing conversion from "unsigned long" to "double"".. . Thanks
i_answer: Yes. It is a feature in C++ 11. `{}` cannot narrow type, otherwise, there is an error.. . You were trying to do something like. ```c++. vector> vec;. . vec.push_back({uint64_t}); // uint64_t cannot be narrowed to double.. . // Do this instead. vec.push_back({static_cast(uint64_t)});. . // vec.size() is a uint64_t, on 64 bits machine. ```

i_answer: Yes, it should be able to find percentiles of one element, and the 0th percentile should just be that element.

subject: percentile question
content: . What are each of these variables? This doesn't explain it very well.. d = . k = . n = . v sub k = . v sub k + 1 = . N = . . Edit: like what they actually represent, not the equations for them.
i_answer: So N is the size of the dataset. Consider the ordered list {15, 20, 35, 40, 50}: N is 5. n is the nth smallest number in the set, given a percentile. So the 40th percentile of the given list is the 2.6th smallest number. So we want to return the 2.6th smallest number in the dataset (obviously the 2nd smallest number is 20). To do this, we split 2.6 up into 2 and 0.6. This is what k and d represent. v sub k is the kth element in the set (so the 2nd element in the ordered set = 20). Then v sub k+1 is the k+1th element of the set (so the 3rd element, or 35). . . See @200 for another explanation.

subject: P1 Style
content: Is there any hand grading for style in 280? Should we have a title for cpp files including our names and stuff? Should we capitalize constants such as epsilon, which is not capitalized in the project spec?
i_answer: There is no style requirements for the first project, but they will begin for the second project. These requirements involve things like function size, line length, repeated code, etc. For style issues such as comments or variable/file names, there isn't anything required of you (you can name them in any way you please), but we highly recommend commenting and using appropriate variable names to help out your IAs in lab/office hours.

subject: Vectors
content: How do I initiate a vector with set dimensions.
i_answer: For P1, you don't have to worry about initiating vectors of a certain size. However, it is useful when trying to conserve memory. You can use member functions resize (creates vector of length n & initializes with default values that can be overwritten later) or reserve (allocates memory for a vector of length n). You'll use these in 281.

subject: 3 submits per day or 3 in total?
content: This might be a stupid question, but I just want to confirm that it's 3 submits PER DAY for project 1 and not 3 submits in total regardless of when you submit it.
i_answer: You're correct! This also means that if you start earlier, you'll get MORE submits because your submits do NOT roll over! If you don't use any of your 3 submits for a given day, that's ok, but then those submits are gone. Even if you don't think you will be able to get many (or any) points on the autograder, it's in your best interest to start submitting early! Why, you ask?. . It will show you if your code compiles on the Autograder. The Autograder environment is typically at least slightly different from the local environment that you use on your personal computer. Sometimes your project will compile and run just fine in XCode/VS/VSCode, but it won't compile on the Autograder. Typically, this is easy to fix and you can debug it by compiling on CAEN (instructions on how to do this are in the mega tutorial), but it really sucks to learn this the day the project is due and waste one of your submits with a submission that doesn't even compile. This happens a lot. It happens every semester. Don't let it happen to you!You can get points for your test suite. For many project, you get points for writing good test cases that reveal bugs in our "buggy solutions". Not only are these (almost free) points, but this can help you figure out how good your test cases are. If you're catching a lot of the bugs on the Autograder and getting a lot of the test case points, you've probably written a great test suite that will help you catch lots of bugs locally before you submit to the Autograder!The Autograder automatically saves a copy of the files you submit. If you go to your submissions and click on one, you'll notice that the files you submit are there at the top as links. If you click on it, it shows your code, exactly as it was when you submitted. Git is the best option we teach you for version control, however, things happen. If your computer breaks before you had a chance to push your code to your Git repository, or you just plain forgot to set up Git, the Autograder will have a backup copy of your code. Every semester, at least one student has their project files corrupted/deleted/etc. If they were using Git (best) or had made previous submits (second best), their code is not all gone!. . As a final clarification, the "total submit number" (999) is essentially arbitrary. We don't actually give you 999 submits. You get 3x the number of days you submit.

subject: Extract_column
content: I don't understand how to use extract_column in the main.cpp? Do I need to use a hashtag(#something) to find it?  Then does it accept an argument?  And if so, then couldn't it accept a wide variety of files?
i_answer: Good question! In main.cpp, we’ve already included `#include "p1_library.h"` , so you should be able to use `extract_column` inside main.cpp. To have a better idea of how you can use this function (i.e. what it returns, if it accepts any argument), it’s helpful to look at its function declaration in `p1_library.h`:. . ![](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjbzu0oqm4ux2g2%2F653b8c406a75b02baee855f57439a275a47fcb56dc2c211897ac50cf634d066f%2Fextract_col.png). . We see that `extract_column` takes in 2 arguments: `filename` and `column_name`. Yes, `extract_column` can accept a wide variety of files, so your main.cpp should read the inputs and pass in the correct file and column names as arguments for `extract_column`. The output will be a vector of doubles, which can be used for the functions you've implemented in `stats.cpp`. Hope that helps!

subject: Public Tests Valgrind Error
content: Hello, my code is passing all the public tests and it shows a '3/3' score, however the 'Valgrind' portion is highlighted in red with a huge 'error output'. I'm a little confused about what this is since my code compiles and works correctly as tested by me (my output matches the sample for both sample files, confirmed using diff ) and indicated by the 3/3 score, but does the Valgrind failure affect my grade? I'm worried since I don't know what the problem is
i_answer: Please update your uniqname as per @6 so we can take a look at your autograder and provide more specific advice!. . Usually valgrind errors suggest you're accessing invalid memory (such as accessing an array out-of-bounds) or using uninitialized memory (e.g. declaring `int x;` and trying to use it without first assigning it a value). The autograder should give the valgrind output, which can point you to where these things are specifically happening (although it can be very verbose, so feel free to make a post if you need help interpreting it!)
