subject: Calling Test Functions in Stats.CPP
content: After Ive written my test cases in stats_tests.cpp, do I need to be calling these test functions in stats.cpp or do we just have to write the tests and that's all? I noticed stats_tests.cpp has not been included in stats.cpp so I would assume we don't need to actually call it, but it kind of defeats the purpose of test functions if we don't implement them? What should I do?
i_answer: stats_tests.cpp is a separate program that includes stats.h and calls and tests its functions. To run your tests, you can compile with make stats_tests.exe and then run the resulting stats_tests.exe.So stats_tests includes stats, not the other way around.

subject: Private test cases: What's a good strategy to do well on the private test cases?
content: ^ the title.. . I got a 3/3 on Autograder, and my output matches the sample outputs on the spec (i.e., the 1 sample for main_test_data.tsv and the 2 samples for HCMST_ver_3.04.tsv).. . I have also written test cases for the functions. Is there anything else I can do to see if my code works properly?. . I'm a bit worried about my grade potentially being affected by private test cases.. . Thank you!
i_answer: It sounds like you’re on the right track with your approach! The best way to do well on the private test cases is by testing your code for potential bugs (I know it’s easier said than done!). One way is to think about “edge” cases: think about “what is the ‘furthest’ I can go before I break the REQUIRES clause?”. For example, if we have a REQUIRES clause that says input has to be an integer greater than 0, we would want to make sure to test by giving the function the value 1 (because this is the “furthest” we can go before breaking the REQUIRES clause if we put the value 0).I would recommend using the REQUIRES clauses as a good starting point, and then thinking about any potential “unique” cases that might be easy to miss out on.Let me know if you have any additional questions!

subject: .at versus [] for vectors - which is better?
content: For a vector v, since v.at() won't let you reference items outside the bounds of the vector, is using .at() better than [] for accessing elements?. . Are there downsides to .at() (in terms of efficiency or otherwise)?. . Thank you!
i_answer: I believe the only downside between using v.at() and v[] is that the v.at() is slower due to it checking for a vector being indexed out of bounds. However, I don’t think it matters too much for EECS 280 as run time doesn’t matter till EECS 281 and it isn’t that much slower. However, you could use v.at() first to check if something is being indexed out of bounds and then could change them back to v[] if everything seems fine.

subject: Debugger: What is it?
content: Is the debugger just what is built into Xcode (like stepping in, step out)  - those functions or are they additional components?
i_answer: TL;DR for David's very in-depth answer!. . A debugger is a actually separate program that "wraps-around" the program you want to debug, letting you go line-by-line and view values of variables. gdb and lldb are two common debuggers that are generally used from the command line, and they have functions for things like "stepping-into", "stepping-over", setting breakpoints, etc. . . The visual debugger that you use from XCode, Visual Studio, or VSCode, is actually just an interface that runs gdb or lldb, but also does nice visual stuff like highlight lines and provide buttons to step over/into (whereas if you were debugging from the command line, you would be typing commands and hitting enter to do everything). Visual debuggers are a little bit easier to use, but we do have tutorials if you want to learn to use gdb/lldb directly!:. * [https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_gdb.html](https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_gdb.html). * [https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_lldb.html](https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_lldb.html)

subject: What is the purpose of merging files on gitLab?
content: After committing and pushing my files using git I was told that source files were one branch behind the main branch and that I needed to merge. What does this mean and is that okay to click merge?.
i_answer: Could you post a screenshot? Its possible you have multiple branches on gitlab, maybe due to main/master branch naming. So you might be making changes on a branch called master locally - could you run `git branch` in a terminal and paste the output here?. . The overall problem is that git's default branch is named master, but gitlab uses main as default - that means gitlab is going to try and bring any code pushed on another branch and "merge" it into main (basically combine the changes from the other branch into main). You're probably okay to hit merge, but I would probably figure out your whole branch situation first so you don't have to think about it

subject: Epsilon in functions
content: I might be overthinking a bit, but am I supposed to use epsilon in functions like mode where two numbers need to be compared? On the one hand, I don't want to have false negatives like 1/3.0 =/= 1 - 2/3.0 if both appear in a vector; but on the other hand, I don't want to have false positives like 3.1415926000 = 3.1415927000 if they appear as two distinct values in a vector. Can we assume the program will always receive fully simplified decimal values from a tsv so that the former case won't occur?
i_answer: Yes you may! In other words, you don't have to worry about using an epsilon to make sure something like 1/3.0 == 1 - 2/3.0 is true for the mode, because we're getting the exact decimal values from the tsv file and only trying to find occurrences of that *exact* value. So you wouldn't see 1/3.0 in a tsv, you would be getting the exact decimal `0.33333333333333331`, and your mode would be looking for how often that occurs.. . This isn't exactly the situation for your test cases though - the doubles you get from your stats functions might have weird rounding errors, so asserting them as exactly equal to the expected decimal number might fail.

subject: Testing Format
content: For my stats_tests, can I have a test function entirely for mode or median that tests multiple data sets within the function? Or do I need to have one mode for small data sets, one for large, etc. (like the example sum test function)
i_answer: You can choose how you want to group your individual test cases into functions, but make sure you're hitting all the cases and edge cases. You are not restricted to 1 test case per function.

subject: Confusion on epsilon?
content: I read through the spec and understand epsilon in the context of the example of the spec.  But, I don't understand how to use it in the functions of our project?
i_answer: The example in the spec that you mention is found in this section: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#appendix-f-comparisons-how-to which is just about some comparison issues you might run into and how to deal with them, so you just need to keep those examples in mind when doing comparisons. So with an epsilon value, you would just need to use it whenever you're checking if two floating point numbers (like floats or doubles) are equal, which is necessary due to issues with rounding.. . So basically I wouldn't stress about finding somewhere to use it, just keep it around in your head for if you ever check if two doubles are equal (you might find more instances of that when writing test cases rather than in your actual implementation)

subject: Question about epsilon?

You will need the function to read/store the information from the tsv files.

subject: Asnswers more than 6 digits
content: Running my test cases every answer greater than 6 digits the assert statements go wrong. I realized it is because the return statement automatically sets the precision to 6, thus the answer goes wrong. . . My standard dev = 169955.7495. while returning I get 169956. . Since the epsilon value is 0.00001, and the difference is approximately 0.25, I get my answer wrong. How do I change this?
i_answer: You need to figure out `double`'s precision and `cout`'s precision. `double`, as a data type, can guarantee 15-18 digits of precision. However, `cout`, as the way you print the `double` out, choose to print 6 significant digits by default.. . If you want to check if the output and expected value are the same, use `assert(abs(output - expected) < epsilon)`.. . To visually check your answer, set `cout.precision(15)` at the very beginning of your code.. . If the value is off by a lot, $$0.25$$ in your example, you need to check your function implementation. It is irrelevant to `double` itself unless the number is very large.

subject: Summarize
content: Can someone give me a hint or something(other than what is given in the stats.h file) about how to do the summarize function?
i_answer: So you basically want to return a vector of pairs (where the pair is also a vector), and each pair is a value with the number of times it appears in the data set. A good way to start is to actually sort the vector that's passed into the function (you can use the sort() helper function for this), that way the numbers are in ascending order and it's easier to count how many times each number appears.

subject: Precision Requirement for double in Project 1
content: In project 1, we are asked to compare some double values. As mentioned in the appendix of project 1 page, we may want to count for the approximation error. However, what epsilon should we use? Are there any restrictions on the precision of double comparison? I currently use epsilon = 0.00001.
i_answer: By convention, we usually use $$1E-5$$, which is also used in examples on the p1 spec page. It is safe to use any epsilon greater than `std::numeric_limits::epsilon`.

subject: Decimal places

And I did not see any instruction on the p1 spec page that tells us we should set the precision manually.. . But the spec page does mention you can increase the precision when you are testing or debugging.

subject: segmentation fault with extract column, Project 1
content: Hi, I'm not sure what the error here is. I included p1_library.h, but the when I try to run the main.exe, there is a segmentation fault before I even print "reading column B from file".. . . . Terminal:
i_answer: You never buffer that last print statement because you do not have << endl at the end (basically meaning it will not show up in the terminal right away), so it is possible and likely that your code is getting past that and segfaulting somewhere else. Using the debugger could be helpful for figuring out when the segfault occurs.. . Edited by David:. . I do not think the lack of flush will cause this issue. Obviously, the line that causes this issue is not in those pictures. Because without Address Sanitizer and UB sanitizer, no one knows what caused this issue.. . By the way, you do not need to flush or endl every time you finish a line. You only need to flush at the very end of your output. So, cout << '\n'; is a more preferable way to print a newline, instead of std::endl.. . Nolan: no it wouldn't cause the issue, but it is why it *appears* that the program crashes before printing that statement. Address Sanitizer and UB sanitizer is a good idea, yes..

subject: How does the vector> work?
content: I’m trying to understand this double vector but is it similar to a two dimensional array or is it something else?
i_answer: Yes, it is similar in a lot of ways. For example, if you had a 2d array of ints, there would be an int at each index, but instead, there is a vector at each index.Also, because it’s a vector and not an array, it can change size.To help visualize, it would look something like this:{{1, 2, 3},{4, 5, 6},{7, 8, 9}}Where the first vector (holds values 1, 2, and 3) would be at index [0] and the value 2 in that vector would be at index [0][1] (row 0, column 1).If you look up “C++ vector of vectors” or something along those lines there are a lot of good explanations.

subject: Private Tests
content: Will the private test cases only run main.cpp (and associated files) and not stats_tests.cpp? I submitted to autograder and received an "call of overloaded 'abs(double)' is ambiguous" error for my test cases, but passed the compile check for the private tests; so was wondering if this is because I only call the abs function in stats_tests.cpp and not my main.cpp.
i_answer: According to the p1 spec page.. . >The functions in `stats.cpp` must still work when compiled with a different main function.. . Okay, your issue is also mentioned on the spec page. Sometimes, the default arguments of your compiler will help it find some missing includes by itself. In this case, your local compiler found `cmath` by itself, so it did not cause any issue on your end. But autograder will not do that favor for you. Thus, you need to manually include `cmath` in your `cpp` files.

subject: Project 1: autograder grade:  the final grade?
content: Will an autograder score of 3/3 be considered as the final score for the project? . Are points deducted for any particular coding practices?. . For example,. 1. Is style graded?. 2. I wrote 2 helper functions in stats.cpp (to make my code cleaner). Is this okay?. 3. The logic I used for my mode function differs from the one given in the hints in the header file. . . Thank you! : )
i_answer: There are private test cases that we run after the deadline, so your grade may change depending on how your code performs against them. However, we always take your best submission (including the private test cases).. . In addition:. 1. Style is graded (you will see a section and your score for style starting from project 2). 2. Helper functions are allowed (just make sure to double-check with the spec for any restrictions). 3. As long as the functionality is working (and we don't say you must use something), then you can use any logic you'd like!. . Just make sure that everything falls in accordance to any restrictions throughout the spec, such as here (https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#tips-tricks-and-restrictions).. . Let me know if you have any other questions!

subject: Lazy Evaluation

subject: How iterators work?

Here's what I tried.. . for (vector<int>::iterator i = v.begin(); i < v.end(); i++) {.   if (*i == num) {.      v.erase(i);.   }. }. . It's working but I don't know how. I thought the index will be messed up if I iterate the vector from beginning to end..
i_answer: As mentioned in the student answer, you shouldn't need to use erase, and many of the functions become much simpler if you sort the vector before you do anything else

subject: vector of vectors
content: How is the size of vector of vectors counted ?. For example, if the vector of vectors is. {.     {1, 2},.     {2, 3},.     {17, 1}. }. is the size 3 since there are three victors?
i_answer: C++ docs is pretty helpful here: https://www.cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/size/.. Basically the size is the number of elements. The subvectors are the elements, and there are 3 of them, so yes, the size is 3.

subject: incrementing vectors
content: Is it possible to increment a vector by writing vector[ ][ ]++ ? What does this mean? In other words, what is actually being incremented with the ++ outside of both sets of brackets? If possible, could you provide an example?
i_answer: The [ ] operator will actually return a reference to that item in the vector. So, if you increment it with ++ (or modify it with the = operator), it will actually change the value in that vector.For instance v[0]++ will increment the first element in the vector v by 1.If you have a vector of vectors, v[0][1] would increment the second element of the first subvector by 1. So if v = {{0,0},{0,0}}, it would become {{0,1},{0,0}} after this operation.

subject: Count Function Error
content: What does this error "implicit conversion loses integer precision" and then it mentions something with regard to double and int mean?
i_answer: Use `static_cast`. Since `size_t` is an `uint64_t` but `int` is an `int32_t`. It could cause implicitly conversion overflow. In our case, we are pretty sure this overflow will not happen. $$2^{31}-1$$ is a very large number. Thus, we choose to explicitly ignore this warning by casting.. . Edit: I answered this question on my iPhone, add more content, and highlight it.

subject: Test Case Grading
content: I'm a bit confused on what kind of test cases I'm supposed to write, and if they'll be graded on "quality". When should we aim to write multiple test cases for a single function and when would one be sufficient? Would we be penalized if our code is correct but we did not realize to test particular edge cases? Finally, should we also test out-of-bounds inputs to show that errors occur, or do we not have to consider those?
i_answer: For this project you'll only be graded for the presence of test cases for each function in stats.cpp. The actual test cases you write is up to you, and you may realize that there are more edge cases for certain functions than others. For example, the count function probably doesn't have many edge cases, but a function like median might have some tricky edge cases (e.g. odd number of values, even number of values, etc.). Lastly, you don't need to test things like out-of-bounds inputs or other invalid inputs.

subject: Stats Functions
content: Should we write our own sort functions for stats.cpp so that our stats functions will work straight away by using the sort function inside the stats function or should we write a stats functions that works without using a sorting function inside because it assumes the input vector is already sorted. I am saying this because there is already a built in sort function in p1_library however I notice that we don't do #include p1_library in our stats.cpp
i_answer: No, those two functions in `p1_library.h` are helper functions prepared for you. Per RMEs, you cannot assume any input is sorted.. . If you check the `restriction` part on p1 spec page, you will find you are allowed to use some STL, standard header files, and `p1_library.h`.

subject: Will autograder be grading stats_tests.cpp?
content: I see that `stats_tests.cpp` has a rough structure already made for us. It looks like the idea is to make one function per data set per statistic?. . To make it so I don't have to write as many functions, I'm planning on designing the file with a struct like this. ```cpp. struct DataSet {.   std::vector data;.   double mean;.   std::vector percentiles;.   double mode;.   int count;.    .... }. ```. and then initializing an array of like 10 `DataSet`s, and then just looping through and testing each one.. . Will autograder (or human grader) be testing this file and looking for a particular format or am I okay to do it like this?
i_answer: The idea is that for each function in stats.cpp there will be function in stats_tests.cpp that will test it, and inside each of the functions in stats_tests, you can have multiple cases/assert statements for the same function. I don't think making a struct/looping is worth it because for future projects it's required to write cases separately anyway.

subject: Standard Deviation output for main_test_data
content: When looking at the sample output in the project spec for main_test_data column B, the stdev value that is outputted is 1.58114. However, when taking the standard deviation of (6,7,8,9,10), the standard deviation is 1,41421. Is there any reason why the output doesn't match the actual standard deviation?
i_answer: The RME for `stdev` references a Wikipedia article section that describes the **corrected sample standard deviation** and gives its formula as $$\sqrt {{\frac {1}{N-1}}\sum _{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}-{\bar {x}}\right)^{2}}$$. Make sure that your implementation matches this formula.

subject: setup using xcode
content: Instead of getting this:. g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe. I'm getting this:. c++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe. . Does anyone know how to fix this?
i_answer: `c++` is a compiler like `g++` or `clang++`. To some degree, they are interchangeable. If you are on macOS, the only difference is their default arguments, since macOS links all compilers to `clang`.. . But if XCode decides to use `c++`, you are good, no further action needs to be done. If you did not encounter any issues, no need to worry.. . It seems like you are at this step. If you are at this step and getting that, you need to check your Makefile. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-07_at_00.30.35.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F842ca2ce71bacb70da16cbde142f18a6398c2b48cde59b26f652ef5511c4f5a8%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-07_at_00.30.35.png). . subject: Tests for stats.cpp
content: Since there will be a lot of irrational numbers (stdev made me realize this but it applies to a lot of the other functions as well), should our asserts test within a certain level of error, like +/- 0.000001?
i_answer: Yes, it's a good idea to do your comparisons within an error tolerance instead of doing exact comparisons due to rounding errors of floating point numbers. If you haven't, check out Appendix F from p1 spec for handling floating point comparisons!

subject: Invalid Argument Error

By convention, we always return a negative number to indicate error.We will learn exceptions at the very end of this semester, you don’t need to worry about throwing an exception.

subject: branch (version control) ????? 🤣

i_answer: Great question! . . It's not needed, but I think making multiple branches per project is always a good idea—doing so allows you to access/keep track of different versions of your code. . The command to create a new branch is: . . git checkout -b <branch name>. Make sure you have navigated to your project folder before typing this in the command line. Also, replace <branch name> with whatever you want your branch to be called :D

i_answer: Private tests results are hidden and unreleased until the project grades are returned. If you've received 3/3, feel free to continue checking over your code or writing additional test cases to ensure everything is solid. Think about possible edge cases that might catch bugs in your code!

subject: median()

subject: Writing statistics Functions?
content: I am a bit confused on what to do in stats_test.cpp and stats.cpp. I assume that we are writing the functions in stats.cpp and testing them in stats_tests.cpp so does that mean we should get rid of all the assert statements in stats.cpp and just write the function definitions. Then later we would write a bunch of assert statements in stats_test.cpp?
i_answer: Yep! Function implementations for sum(), count(), mean(), etc. are written in stats.cpp. So you should get rid of the assert statements in each function stub.. . And in stats_test.cpp, you'll be testing the function implementations through assert statements.

subject: Is CAEN Linux set-up required to complete the projects?
content: If code is submitted to autogravder and compiles without an error, is this necessary?
i_answer: You don't necessarily need CAEN, but it's super useful for checking that your code will compile on a similar environment to the AG, and for style checking!

subject: Is it required that we set up the gitlab part in order to complete project 1?
content: Is it required that we set up the gitlab part in order to complete project 1?
i_answer: Not required, but HIGHLY recommended. If you ever lose your code (accidently delete your folder) or if your computer suddenly stops working, having GitLab set-up and making sure to regularly save your code there allows you to download your previous work and continue working off of it on a separate device.

subject: The term "in v"
content: Hello, . . I am getting the error "No viable conversion from returned value of type 'vector<double>' to function return type 'double" when I try to return my function in V. Im not sure what I am doing wrong. Code attachedScreen_Shot_2022-01-06_at_7.02.55_PM.png
i_answer: “double” is like a decimal (e.g. 3.3), while “v” here is a vector of doubles, so instead of returning the vector of doubles, you want to just return the sum (as a double/decimal) itself!

subject: Question
content: Hello,. . I had a quick question. I was working on some test cases and had a question. Are we allowed to use min(), max(), and sort() or no?
i_answer: You are not allowed to use functions from the C++ algorithm library in your code e.g. ```std::sort()```, ```std::min()```, ```std::max()```. but you can use any function in ```p1_library.h```, including the sort function in this file. Let me know if you have any more questions!

subject: Why isn't modf and pow running on my program?
content: This is the error I get when I try to run my tests:. . ‘modf’ was not declared in this scope; did you mean ‘mode’?. . I thought that modf was part of the functions that was provided in the appendix. I'm not sure how this is not working. . Same thing for pow. It's supposed to square something but it's not doing it. It's a basic cmath function so Idk why this is happenign
i_answer: Hmm my quick guess would be did you include the line #include <cmath> in your file? That’s the C++ library where those functions are defined. . As per the followups, also include the line #include <math.h> for modf.

subject: What is all of this git stuff?

Again, I would recommend going through the tutorial we have to make sure you have everything set up and everything is clear.

subject: summarize() Values
content: Are we assuming that the value [in (value, frequency)] will always be a whole number?  They vector type is double, so I assumed we should be allowing for doubles as well. . . If we are allowing for doubles, how are we handling rounding?  I know the epsilon value is 0.00001 for floating point comparison, so are we rounding to the hundred-thousandths place when we present the summarized values (assuming input values could extend past the hundred-thousandths place)?. . Thanks in advance.
i_answer: The input vector allows for double values so the values in the summary should probably also be doubles.In the case of rounding, I don’t think there is much reason to round. The project specifications just asks for the values from the data.

(such as your Mac login username, your name, etc.) The example is specific for user `awdeorio`, meaning that the path to their Desktop does through a folder called `awdeorio` (which may not be on your computer in the folder `Users`, unless you had made one and put your Desktop on there). . In any case, this part (let me know if I'm referring to a wrong part) could be any path to a folder that you would remember, for instance, I might use `/Users/zwgold/Desktop/eecs_280/`. Make sure to also use the 'cd' command at the front, per the first note in the "Create a folder" section.

subject: Error initializing the repo
content: Why do I get this error when I try to initialize the repo using git init? Any help would be appreciated, thanks!. . $ git initerror: chmod on /mnt/c/Users/jessw/Desktop/EECS 280/p1-stats/.git/config.lock failed: Operation not permittedfatal: could not set 'core.repositoryformatversion' to '0'
i_answer: This error could happen when you access a web storage disk from Linux. In this case, if you are running a OneDrive backup on your Windows, there might be a permission issue. . . The best way is to move your working directory inside Linux, which means move to `~` by `cd ~` (home directory).

So I restarted the tutorial and realized when I used the git init command this popped up.. . hint: Using 'master' as the name for the initial branch. This default branch namehint: is subject to change. To configure the initial branch name to use in allhint: of your new repositories, which will suppress this warning, call:hint: hint:   git config --global init.defaultBranch <name>hint: hint: Names commonly chosen instead of 'master' are 'main', 'trunk' andhint: 'development'. The just-created branch can be renamed via this command:hint: hint:   git branch -m <name>. . Then I just did git config '--global init.defaultBranch main.' So later on in the tutorial when I used git push -u origin main it did not give me an error.

subject: Setup Tutorial and P1 FAQ
content: Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions regarding the setup tutorial and Project 1.  The setup tutorial itself is linked on the eecs280 website.  Project 1 is due Wednesday, January 19 at 8pm.  Please keep the followups related to questions in this post only.. . Q: I get this error when trying to run VSCode on WSL (error starting the pipe progam):  . . . A: Try changing:. . . "pipeProgram": "c:\windows\sysnative\bash.exe",. to. . . "pipeProgram": "/mnt/c/Windows/System32/bash.exe",. in the launch.json. . Q: I’m trying to debug my project with VSCode on Mac, but it’s skipping all my breakpoints. What do I do?. . A: This is a known bug in the Microsoft C/C++ extension. Try installing the `CodeLLDB` extension with the following steps:. . . In VSCode, go to the Extensions tab and search for “CodeLLDB”. . . Set your `launch.json` configuration to the following:. . . . { "name": "(lldb) Launch",. "type": "lldb",. "request": "launch",. "program": "${workspaceFolder}/stats_tests.exe",. "args": [],. "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",. }. Q: I’m getting an error in CAEN when I try to compile my code that looks like. . /usr/bin/ld: cannot find /usr/lib64/libasan.so.0.0.0. . collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status. . make: *** [stats_tests.exe] Error 1. . A: Try changing the gcc version by running the following command:. . . module load gcc/7.1.0. You can add the following command to automatically change the gcc version every time you log in:. . . echo "module load gcc/7.1.0" >> ~/.bash_profile. Q: Why am I unable to view console output in macOS vsCode?. . A: For Mac users on VSCode, install the “codeLLDB” extension instead of the “C/C++” extension and then set externalConsole to “true”. Now when you run the visual debugger, it will open a new “Terminal” window. . Q: I’m getting the error that “call of overloaded abs(double) is ambiguous” when I’m trying to compare floating points as used in Appendix F of the spec.. . A: Try adding #include <cmath> to the top of the file.. . Q: I haven't worked with vectors before - are there any recommended resources?. . A: You can find a number of vector tutorials online that give a decent introduction. Additionally, here are some links to the ENGR 101 Runestone materials with an introduction to vectors in C++. (These links are to a development server that isn't terribly reliable, but it avoids you having to make a Runestone account. If it doesn't load immediately, try refreshing the page a few times until it does.). . Vectors in C++: http://lobster.eecs.umich.edu:8000/vectors_in_cpp/main.html. Vectors of Vectors, relevant for summarize(): http://lobster.eecs.umich.edu:8000/more_data_structures/main.html. . Q: When I ssh into CAEN, I get put in the root folder (/) instead of my home directory (/home/uniqname/). . A: For some reason, your home directory was not created automatically. You can request for one to be created for you at the IFS storage request page. . . pinittowinit.
